p: Taking into account the importance of the k z-dispersion and very small gaps caused by anisotropic Weyl cones implied by the calculations, we have performed both very detailed photon energy dependent measurements and high-resolution measurements near the calculated Weyl points (Supplementary Note 1). It turned out that the mentioned earlier photon energies at which the FS contours were sharp and continuous approximately correspond to k z-locations of either second set of Weyl points or the minimum gaps, naturally explaining the observed effect since the k z-dispersion in these regions is negligible. However, even at hν = 20 eV we could not clearly resolve the tiny gaps and in both cases we observed qualitatively similar distribution of spectral weight near the Fermi level, as if the Weyl points existed at both k zs.
